got a flat black and I've got this stone texture paint now the reason I use the

then you won't have these as much stone texture and it's the more expensive so

one last thing I'd like to talk about are the measuring sticks that I
mentioned earlier like I say with my dungeon tiles I don't put squares on
there I feel it's very bored gamey and the characters feel they have to go to a
square just feels very restrictive to me so we use is we use the war game war
game method where we measure so basically I just make sticks rulers are
kind of intrusive they're big so I make sticks out of quarter-inch wood and this
one here is just a character stick and it's got six inches measured on it so
the character can measure from their location to the other location to the
next location I've also got a longer stick that I've measured out 24 inches
and for you know long-range weapons or whatever so those work great and it's
really not that much more difficult and it just really adds to the immersion not
to have to count squares like you're on a board game or stand in a square like
you're in a board game characters can bunch up together they
can move where they want without feeling that they're restricted by a square so I
would really consider doing this and like I say it's super easy to implement
so there are my sticks so here's an example of the sticks in
play so I've got my dungeon tile with the binding on the front the characters
come to this area and they they may uncover this vine-covered entrance and
so they do they can explore this crypt so say my one character this druid here
decides that she wants to move in so instead of counting the six tiles it
would be on a regular dungeon tile she could put the stick down and then move
to six inches and there you go so she's moved her six inches and
there's no restriction so say this character want to move in she could do
the say she only moved five inches so you would just mark the five inches and
she couldn't move quite as far so she'd be there so couldn't be easier and so
the gnome say he's only five inches so he would move he could move there or he
could move really close to her or hide behind her since he's a gnome of course
and there's no restriction as far as the squares on them on the grid where they
can move they can move where they want and I really like that I think it really
helps the immersion and that's just a small example of how that work
